title: ما شكل العلاقة بين دمشق وواشنطن بعد زيارة الشرع؟

segments.text: This is a podcast worth your attention from BBC Arabic News, and I am Mohamed Al-Sheikh.
I welcome my guest from Abu Dhabi, Dr. Samir Al-Taqi, the senior researcher at the Atlantic Council in Washington, USA.
Welcome, Dr. Samir.
Hello, I am honored to be with you and your audience, and of course, with BBC.
Welcome, Doctor. As we record this episode...
The first official visit in the history of the Syrian Republic by a Syrian president to the United States is taking place.
Many see this visit as potentially changing the narrative.
Let's start by understanding the significance of this visit.
Regardless of the interpretations, analyses, and forecasts...
Because we will delve into them later.
The importance of the visit from the perspective of Syrian nationalism is very significant.
Because, practically, Syria is reclaiming its identity as a normal state.
As a state that belongs to the world.
As a state that does not belong to rogue nations, but rather to normal countries that aspire to develop themselves.
At the same time, this shift reflects a change in the American stance, not just towards Syria.
But towards the entire region.
Practically, the region is in a fluid state extending beyond borders.
It feels like we are standing in the region on shifting sands.
And the United States views Syria.
As one of the most dangerous areas, considering that any issue there could impact the entire surrounding environment.
Syria is a pivotal state in its regional context.
Therefore, it was essential for the United States to assert its influence as it did in Iraq, directly.
After the United States had refrained in any way from any form of nation-building.
Currently, it is directly involved in reshaping the Syrian army and the security structure and the diplomatic and strategic environment surrounding Syria.
In this regard, it has managed to neutralize the main contradiction between Turkey and Israel.
So the shift is from both sides.
Perhaps this statement you made about Syria transitioning from being a state in limbo, as you described it.
According to the American description, of course.
This was perhaps during the years when the Ba'ath Party was in power.
It was the ruling party of the state and society in Syria, as it defined itself.
But before that, Syria was a republic with its own weight, a country closer to, let's say, democracy.
However, there was a rift with the United States.
What caused this rift and what has changed today?
I believe that in the 1950s, for example, there was a rift.
In the 1950s, there was a significant role for American travel in Damascus.
In the relationship, even with the Ba'ath leadership and even with the leaders of the Syrian Communist Party.
This means that the United States viewed itself.
As being different from the approaches of both France and Britain.
And that it wanted to offer a way out for the region.
Thus, there was a matter.
However, the conflict over Syria was primarily ignited through the events following the Suez Crisis.
And subsequently, this led to unity, separation, and the rise of the Ba'ath Party to power.
All these phases were characterized by severe instability.
In my opinion, this prevented Syria from directly engaging in this arena.
Immediately after that, Syria objectively aligned itself with the anti-American camp.
Therefore, I imagine that there was a window of opportunity in the 1950s.
The Americans were betting a lot on Syria.
But their patience was short as usual.
However, no Syrian president has ever visited the United States.
No head of state has gone to the United States.
At certain stages, there was no presence of a Syrian political mindset.
There was no direct connection between Israel and the United States.
The connection was more closely tied between France, Britain, and the United States.
We recall in 1956 how the United States brought France, Britain, and Israel down.
By forcing them out of the Suez Canal.
All of this laid a foundation that the United States could have developed regarding its position in the region.
However, it seems that the Soviet Union made its decisions more decisively than the United States.
Let's return to this visit, and you also acknowledged that there are many contradictions.
One of the contradictions is that the Syrian transitional president, Ahmad al-Shara,
was listed on American and even international terrorism lists.
His name and that of the Minister of Interior were removed from the terrorism lists ahead of or during this visit.
So how is this matter interpreted in diplomatic customs and political thought?
That the man was at the height of hostility towards a specific place or country.
Now he appears to be an ally in one way or another.
Firstly, the definition of terrorism in international relations collapses based on these actions.
But more importantly, the West in general, particularly Britain for example,
had a stance against Jomo Kenyatta in Kenya.
He was considered a terrorist and a criminal, and there was a warrant out for his arrest.
The main problematic issue in the American stance that differs.
Is that Mr. Al-Shara comes with a force that has not managed the conflict well.
Regarding the issue of jihadist allegiance and the matter of loyalty to the Syrian homeland.
The problem is that there is a gamble, which reflects the level of need for the United States.
To find itself as a platform to manipulate the regional situation in the Levant.
Therefore, it is taking a serious risk, but there are conditions involved.
If we read the texts of the Security Council resolutions under Chapter Seven.
Regarding what is required from the Syrian government.
As if it is placing Syria under a form of international mandate.
Concerning the recruitment of terrorists and reconciliation with various components, and so on.
Thus, it is practically a very narrow corridor offered to the Syrian leadership.
As much as Mr. al-Shara wanted to go to Iraq to expel the Americans.
He came and brought the Americans to Damascus.
This indicates the level of shift that has occurred in the Syrian situation, not specifically in Mr. Al-Shara's position.
But this wouldn't have happened if there wasn't another party, and the American side was receptive to this idea.
In fact, they have been promoting it from the very beginning.
Many believe that what is happening now might be a political tactic rather than a real transition.
What is your reading on this point between the tactic and the actual transition to the American camp?
I am not talking about the Syrian leadership.
In my opinion, the Syrian leadership has long joined and will continue to join.
And America will fight and do everything possible to keep Syria in its current state from its alliance perspective.
As for whether the Syrian leadership will be able to commit to what it promises.
That would be a problem for the United States and for the region.
Therefore, I believe that it is a tactical issue; no, it is not tactical, it is a gamble, it is an opportunity.
Practically, these are the available cards, and they are few for the United States.
The evidence is what is happening in Gaza, Syria, and Lebanon; these are limited cards.
However, the United States is engaging and risking the reputation of its president.
This is due to its need to gain positions on the ground to stabilize its situation.
It is a gamble; it is not either this or that. It is a gamble: if it succeeds, it will be good, and if it does not succeed...
In my opinion, America is already calculating for scenario B.
It will not abandon the SDF forces, nor will it allow harm to come to our people in the Druze Mountain.
All of this is part of the direct discussions taking place with Mr. Al-Shara.
About the state's structure and its construction, and about retaining forces specific to the various components.
Until the central structure of the state is practically established.
This is a conversation that is openly happening in Washington.
Talking about locations, and they might refer to geographical sites on the ground.
There was a report from Reuters discussing American military bases that could be established inside Syria, specifically in Damascus.
Or at the Al-Sin airport, which is part of the Syrian external territory.
However, the numerous reports frequently point to this issue.
Is the United States really interested in having a tangible military presence on the ground in Syria?
Meaning a presence that aligns with the desires of the Syrian government.
I believe the Syrian government is willing, but the issue is related to saving face.
As is the case in the Iraqi context, there is much discussion happening in Iraq.
However, in practice, the military forces at Ain al-Asad play a key role for the Americans.
They play a major role in training, guidance, and security coordination, among other things.
I believe we should not envision anything like this, and even more than that.
The situation is related to the fact that the situation in Syria and the region connected to Syria is extremely turbulent.
And the United States, as long as it has decided to engage with its military presence.
This is a rare action for the United States to take.
It was unlikely that Trump himself would do this, but he wants to establish these shifting sands.
So I assume that yes, we will hear a lot of denial and many planes landing and monitoring.
And then it is said that it was not intentional; it was merely logistical and not for surveillance, and so on.
I believe that, practically, the United States is gaining critical positions regarding military oversight.
And practically, the training of the army, as is happening in Iraq, is also aimed at preparing the Syrian army to be part of the strategic framework.
This is primarily anti-terrorism and the American label in the region, unlike any other.
Doctor, you spoke here about terrorism and the presence of the United States, and the importance of this presence in combating terrorism.
There are also negotiations for Syria's joining the camp against the organization known as the Islamic State.
And the United States and the majority of the world consider it a terrorist organization.
However, on the other hand, there is another perspective; there are messages to countries that have historically been allies of Syria, such as Russia.
Between the Assad era and even before it.
So how will traditional allies view Syria, especially since the legitimate president recently visited Russia?
I mean, I believe that the notion that his visit changes anything, in my opinion.
A visit to Russia cannot be compared to a visit to Washington in terms of importance.
We cannot say that there is a balance in this regard; this is a kind of political nonsense.
The practical truth is that Russia has lost Syria.
What Russia has lost most in Syria is not Bashar al-Assad, but the Syrian army.
This army, which it nurtured and built, was practically injected with all the requirements and principles of Soviet military doctrine, or what we now call Russian.
This loss is a major setback, and Russia has also lost the role it was tasked with.
There was a Western-American agreement with Russia for it to be the power broker in the region.
The balance of power between Turkey, Israel, Iran, and also the Syrian opposition and the Syrian regime.
Even some Arab countries were involved, which gave Russia a highly significant position with very little investment.
And these two small bases in Syria.
This issue is not repeatable; there will no longer be any Western mandates in the context of the resulting geostrategic transformations.
Regarding two issues: the first is the Ukrainian war, and then the events of October 7th.
That will not be the case; on the contrary, the Eastern Mediterranean today is an unfriendly sea for the Russian navy.
In my opinion, from an investment perspective, the presence of Russian military bases is unjustified.
The arming of the Syrian army will not, in the strategic long term, be reliant on Russia.
We need to know who the enemy is; is it Israel, and what form will the weapon take?
However, if the goal is merely to manage and control the internal situation, then the mission is entirely different.
So, don't expect, for example, that there will be a rebuilding of the Syrian army by American forces or training for the Syrian army.
The main comparison I always reiterate is the comparison with the Iraqi army.
There will be no air force; there will be no anti-aircraft missiles.
But only initially with the aim of combating terrorism.
Because, as I said, we first need to know who the enemy is in order to determine what the army is, what the armament is, what the budget is, and who the allies are.
And within the framework of the alliance with the United States, which is currently favorable.
The security missions of the Syrian army are solely related to border protection and nothing else.
Regarding the definition of terrorism.
Israel also imposes conditions on the development of even the types of drones that are allowed to be developed in Syria.
The types of missiles that Israel can develop in negotiations.
It imposes conditions on the development of Syrian military industries in all their fields.
Regarding terrorism, the definition of terrorism also agrees on the issue of weapons.
What about the issue of terrorism?
Many of the factions that have now joined the new Syrian army helped the legitimate president come to power.
They were listed on the lists that the United States considers as terrorist organizations.
And there is a problem, as you mentioned, regarding the ideology that these groups hold.
How will the United States assist the Syrian president, Ahmad al-Shar'i, in perhaps reshaping certain concepts?
These concepts have been resistant for a long time to all the political expertise in the world in changing perspectives.
The Americans are experimenting with the Syrians.
In practice, General Petraeus has a theory that the best way to combat terrorism is by using jihadists of the same caliber.
And I believe that this is practically an experiment that may have succeeded in some cases.
For example, we can take the case of Northern Ireland where it was possible to reach an agreement to disarm the fighters.
However, the mechanisms are completely different, and the level of ideological fervor is very high here.
Therefore, the impressions even among American circles are that it is impossible to expect a jihadist ideological shift for entire groups of people.
Even if they are bribed, given salaries, and their conditions improved, along with temptations.
However, the issue is that some of them actually come from socially privileged backgrounds, and thus the jihadist objective remains intact.
Therefore, all serious experts in the field of counter-terrorism argue that it is impossible to change positions.
This means a complete shift in the positions of large jihadist groups as blocs away from jihadist objectives, especially since jihadist factions need an enemy.
Now, peace is being made with Israel, and the relationship with the United States is strategically revealed.
So there is a very tumultuous transition, which is even different from the situation of the Iraqi militias.
As for the factions themselves, from their perspective, how do they assess this visit or how will they respond to what results from this visit?
We are still within the realm of speculations on major files, but the most important is the existing ideological file.
Many factions loyal to the Syrian government still retain their jihadist agenda.
We notice that even before traveling to Washington, discussions began about groups that were said to be affiliated with ISIS.
However, in practice, many of them do not have a clear historical connection; the area is gray between jihadist organizations.
This includes those that were present in Idlib, jihadist organizations, or practically ISIS, extending to groups like Hurras al-Din and others.
Therefore, I believe, as you mentioned, there will be implications related to the changing tactics of these organizations, going underground or underwater, as we say.
They start acting as an opposition force in various forms; they have financial resources and some areas where loyalties are still mixed.
Whether towards the Syrian government or the historical ideologies of jihadists, all of this raises questions indeed about the future of these groups and how they will be dealt with.
The United States is directly involved in this process, both directly and through the anti-terrorism coalition; it will bear part of the responsibility for this significant gamble.

What about the stance of some allied countries to President Bashar al-Assad's regime, like Turkey, for example, after this visit? Turkey has loyalties and alliances within these factions or among some of these factions that it supports.
In my opinion, Turkey is a nation-state, and I do not expect that in the end, it will base its policies on ideological interests; it uses ideological aspects to advance its own interests.

Thus, I believe that Turkey now finds the recent developments suitable for it and welcomes them, but it is now seriously questioning the implications of the realities on the ground, which show that the Israelis are also getting involved in the Syrian situation intensively.

They are wandering the streets of Damascus, and thus there is competition accepted by both parties. However, in any case, for Turkey, it would be beneficial to support a regime that it contributed to bringing to power.
Regarding the coalition that will confront the Islamic State organization, what will the shape of Syrian participation in this coalition look like?

The illusions related to the idea that a story will be resolved and that it will be forcibly integrated or pressured by the Americans into the Syrian army should remind us of the experience of the Peshmerga in Iraq and all that.

In short, the essence of the matter is that there has been or will be a practically established coalition in the recent military operations conducted by the United States against some jihadist positions said to be affiliated with ISIS.

In practice, the Free Syrian Army participated, as did the SDF, and in a key informational aspect, the Syrian army was involved. Thus, it can be envisioned that this coalition and operational cooperation will be developed, rather than military integration.

I believe that operational cooperation should be fully depicted, and this will lead to strengthening this trend. In my opinion, I do not envision any attempts at forced integration; even in the American experience against ISIS, there was no practical attempt to integrate.

On the contrary, they are now separating the Popular Mobilization Forces from the Iraqi army, the Peshmerga from the Iraqi army, and the SDF from other US-aligned forces. I do not believe they will carry out any forced integration.
Many thanks to Dr. Samir al-Taqi, the senior researcher at the Atlantic Council in the United States.
I hope I was helpful.
Thank you very much, and you have fulfilled your purpose, Doctor. Thank you.
